text: He's generous of spirit.
He has humility.
He is extremely powerful.

He was a-- when I say
powerful, not in just who he
is, powerful in your presence.
He was a basketball player.

He could palm a ball,
so his hands are large.

He has wisdom that has
come from working quietly

in the background, not
wanting for people to know

all the things he does
or does for someone.

I wanted to apply a
good dose of dignity.

I asked him to wear
to our first sitting

exactly what he thinks he would
wear for his portrait sitting.
He came.

He had on a charcoal
gray pinstripe

suit, a purple and white striped
shirt, and a purple polka dot
tie.
Yes, he did.

I said to myself,
this is a nightmare.
He smiles.

So we had about a 2 and 1/2 hour
interview of which I probably

did about 200 photographs,
photo references.

So sometimes, I'm
right on him because I
need to know how this sits.

Or when he's smiling, what
happens up here, you have--
just like--
and he accepted that very well.

But we did a lot of talking,
so that I could also do
a little bit of an interview.

There were something
like 13 drawings

that I had to send
to the committee.
Each one different.

Each one based on the
sitting with Dr. Cash.

The first drawing
I did was based

on something Dr. Cash
thought he wanted,

which was students
in his portrait.
He's a very humble man.

And he did not want
a portrait that he

thought was about him, which
kept making my job harder.

Because the portrait
is about you.
And-- but that's OK.
Because I had to--

I have to find that humility
and put it in that portrait.
My first one, it's him.
He's sort of smiling.
And he's seen it.

And he's doing
something like this.
And there's students around him.
I sent that.

Then they said, we'd
like to see another one.
These discussions went.

Everybody said, we have
to let go of the students.
He was fine with that.

You have to let
go the computers.
He was very fine with that.

Finally, he decided he
would be standing, no smile.
I'm painterly.
I'm not a photo realist.

I'm trying to put the man
in my mind on the canvas.
It's oil.
Oil takes a long time to dry.

I did thin layers,
just very thin.

And they would dry quicker than
my usual brush, brush, brush.
And so they were thin and thin.
I piled it up.

If it was in my studio now,
I'd still be working on it.
Paintings are never done.
I just stop action and continue.

I knew I was done when Melissa
said the shippers are coming
on February 17.
I knew that I had to be done.

And when Jim hugged me and
said I love it, I was so happy.

To come see it in its home
is even more rewarding

in the sense that it
is in a place where

it's going to live probably long
after I'm gone, in a place I

could bring my granddaughters
to and tell them about the man

and tell them I was
able to do his portrait.
It's monumental.
